rules.title: Guidelines for New Rules
rules.abstract: Each rule must conform to a structure to meet the needs of the audience. Rules apply to an element and become part of the element defintition in the Style Guide. A well-written and consistent set of rules assists the reader to understand the use of the element.

rule.rule-statement: Rules that relate to a specific element are included in that element topic.
rule.justification: Grouping rules by element provide a coherent presentation to the Style Guide user. It makes it clear which rule applies to a specific element. If a rule applies to more than one element, it is likely a topic for the General Writing Rules section of the map.

examplefig.codeblock: <rule-statement>Use the <shortdesc> element as the first sentence in the >abstract< element. </rule-statement>

examplefig.desc: The inclusion of multiple use-cases means that this <rule-statement> is not found in all the right places and can be missed by busy readers.
examplefig.codeblock: <rule-statement>When titles in concepts, reference, or troubleshooting topics can be expressed as acronyms, reference their glossentry.</rule-statement>

rule.rule-statement: Group each element definition with its examples in a single <slide-section> element.
Provide good and bad examples of the rule.
rule.justification: Examples give users another form of explanation for the <rule-statement> and expand the potential for understanding the rule.
As discussed in Define a style guide per language the requirements of different languages will vary. Follow the best practices for the language you are writing about.

rule.rule-statement: Include an abstract with a short description to new element topics.
Include a justification to expand on the reasons for the rule.
rule.justification: The <justification> element provides the rationale for the rule. This element gives you the opportunity to explain the background for the rule.
